pullRequest.body:
First PR in a sequence to implement the notion of topological entropy for maps using Bowen-Dinaburg's formalism. This file describes a notion of _dynamical uniformities_, which generalizes dynamical balls in metric spaces.

- [x] Dynamical uniformities
- [ ] Topological entropy via covers
- [ ] Topological entropy via nets
- [ ] Behaviour for subsets
- [ ] Behaviour under morphisms
- [ ] Behaviour under union
- [ ] Behaviour under products
- [ ] Full shift

This file is pretty short; the next ones are more involved.

Paging @pitmonticone @sgouezel 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [eae70a2a65](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14938/commits/eae70a2a65cfb0f4fe8065fb5b406ee4ab349f78)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Dynamics.TopologicalEntropy.DynamicalEntourage`|647|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ _root_.Function.Semiconj.preimage_dynEntourage`
`+ _root_.SymmetricRel.dynEntourage`
`+ _root_.isOpen.dynEntourage`
`+ dynEntourage`
`+ dynEntourage_antitone`
`+ dynEntourage_comp_subset`
`+ dynEntourage_eq_inter_Ico`
`+ dynEntourage_mem_uniformity`
`+ dynEntourage_monotone`
`+ dynEntourage_one`
`+ dynEntourage_univ`
`+ dynEntourage_zero`
`+ idRel_subset_dynEntourage`
`+ mem_ball_dynEntourage`
`+ mem_ball_dynEntourage_comp`
`+ mem_dynEntourage`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Thanks SÃ©bastien for this review!

With respect to naming convention: I have some doubts about a couple of lemmas. These are `Monotone.dynEntourage_entourage` and `Antitone.dynEntourage_time`. On the one hand, a positional naming convention looks more standard to me: `Monotone.dynEntourage_middle` and `Antitone.dynEntourage_right`, for instance. On the other hand:

- I'm not quite sure how to make it work when there are more variables (which happens in the next file...). How to state that something is monotone with respect to the third of four variables? Even _middle_ feels slightly dubious.
- this can be annoying when passing arguments from one function to another. For instance, when I am working with the _time_ variable, it makes sense to me to only call lemmas about _time_, instead of calling sometimes something about the third variable, sometimes about the fourth, etc.

The newer version still have my old naming convention in this respect, but I'm open to any suggestion.
Can you resolve the conversations you have dealt with? In this way, it's easier to spot what remains to be done.
@D-Thomine Finished golfing

bors r+
Thanks!

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10290866205/job/28481844411)

Can you merge master, fix the build, and then send it back to bors?
bors d+

:v: D-Thomine can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10358210913/job/28671889740)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10358210913/job/28671890613)
The content is good, but the names of the lemmas need fixing. I've made suggestions for the first half, and I'll let you come up with your own names for the second half following the motives.
Could you explain what this is in the docstring, not assuming that the reader knows what dynamical balls are?
Done. Pietro, does the new docstring looks informative enough for you?

```suggestion
theorem dynEntourage_eq_inter_Ico (T : X â X) (U : Set (X Ã X)) (n : â) :
```
Also, all the theorems should be lemmas: `theorem` is only for important results, with docstrings.
Done.

```suggestion
theorem mem_dynUniformity {T : X â X} {U : Set (X Ã X)} {n : â} {x y : X} :
```

```suggestion
theorem mem_ball_dynEntourage {T : X â X} {U : Set (X Ã X)} {n : â} {x y : X} :
```

The uniformity is the uniform structure, but here it's not what you are talking about, you are creating a neighborhood of the diagonal, called an entourage. So the name should probably be `dynEntourage`. Note that it should be lower case per our naming convention.

Done.

I tried to follow Topology.UniformSpace.Basic, which weirdly enough, manages to never use the word "entourage" outside of the docstrings...

```suggestion
theorem dynEntourage_mem_uniformity [UniformSpace X] {T : X â X} (h : UniformContinuous T)
```

```suggestion
theorem idRel_subset_dynEntourage (T : X â X) {U : Set (X Ã X)} (h : idRel â U) (n : â) :
```
Don't try to be creative with names, and follow the sequence of symbols in the name unless there is a good reason not to.

```suggestion
theorem SymmetricRel.dynEntourage (T : X â X) {U : Set (X Ã X)} (h : SymmetricRel U) (n : â) :
```
(For use with dot notation).

```suggestion
theorem dynEntourage_comp_subset (T : X â X) (U V : Set (X Ã X)) (n : â) :
```

```suggestion
- `dynEntourage`: dynamical entourage associated with a given transformation `T`, entourage `U`
```

```suggestion
/-- The dynamical entourage associated to a transformation `T`, entourage `U` and time `n` is the set
```

```suggestion
lemma _root_.IsOpen.dynEntourage [TopologicalSpace X] {T : X â X} (T_cont : Continuous T)
```
To enable dot notation

```suggestion
lemma dynEntourage_monotone (T : X â X) (n : â) :
```
There is only one thing wrt which it is monotone, so I don't think it's worth being specific.
Done, but now there are lemmas called `dynEntourage_monotone` and `dynEntourage_antitone` :)

```suggestion
lemma dynEntourage_zero_eq_univ {T : X â X} {U : Set (X Ã X)} :
```
No need to specify it's the time, because what else?

```suggestion
lemma dynEntourage_antitone (T : X â X) (U : Set (X Ã X)) :
```

```suggestion
lemma dynEntourage_one {T : X â X} {U : Set (X Ã X)} :
```

```suggestion
lemma dynEntourage_univ {T : X â X} {n : â} :
```

```suggestion
lemma _root_.SymmetricRel.dynEntourage (T : X â X) {U : Set (X Ã X)} (h : SymmetricRel U) (n : â) :
```
Since you're in a namespace, you need `_root_` to get out of this namespace.

```suggestion
namespace Dynamics
```
You don't need to have a very specific namespace, you just want to make sure that you're not spoiling the root namespace.

```suggestion
  rw [dynEntourage, preimage_iInterâ]
```
`unfold` is essentially never useful, use `rw` instead.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Dynamics): add TopologicalEntropy.DynamicalUniformity
